The height property is used to specify the height of an element. It refers to the percentage or the amount of units (px, em, vh, etc.) of space that the element will take. More precisely, height defines the height of a box; depending on the value of the box-sizing property, the value of the height will be used as the height of the whole element, including paddings, margins and border (box-sizing: border-box); otherwise, the height will be used as the height of the content of the element, excluding paddings, margins and borders that will eventually make the element bigger (box-sizing: content-box).
More about box-sizing: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/box-sizing.

The properties min-height and max-height are usually used to enhance the responsiveness, and they respectively refer to the minimum height and the maximum height the element can have.
These properties have an effect only in specific cases: if the height of an element is smaller than its min-height, then the height property will be overwritten with the min-height value; if, in the same way, the height of the element is bigger than its max-height, then the height property will be overwritten with the max-height value.

For example, consider the following CSS code:

img {
    height: 100%;
    max-height: 300px;
    min-height: 100px;
}

The image will cover the whole page, as long as its height is smaller than 300px and bigger than 100px. Otherwise, its height will be set to 100px if it is smaller, or 300px if it is bigger.

bodyMarkdown:
There is a race condition in the CanvasGame class test "should clear the canvas when started". Conceptually the test creates a 2x2 white spot on the canvas every 50ms (using setInterval). 1. The test comes first, finds a clean black canvas, the test passes, then the white spot generator creates a new white spot.
2. The white spot generator comes first, places a white spot on the canvas, the test comes second and fails.

bodyMarkdown:
`response.render()` is a function used to render a view that should be passed as a first argument - string matching the name of the view file stripped from the extension, for example, if the view is specified in file 'index.ejs' then the function will look like this: `response.render('index');` After rendering it returns the rendered html to the client, so it affects what the client will see on the page. The URL stays the same during the whole function.

`response.redirect()` is a function used to redirect a client to a different URL specified as a string parameter passed to this function. For example, `response.redirect('/index')`  will redirect the client to '/index' which actually means sending a new request but now with '/index' as a path and waiting for a response coming after this new request and sending that response to the client. URL will change from the one the client wanted to the one specified in the redirect, so it affects what the client will see as the URL.

I think the easiest way would be to execute the callback function from then or catch, depending on if everything went well or there was an error. That way, after the execution of the asynchronous function inside the promise is finished, the callback function will be appropriately called.

To make this "invisible", we can encapsulate this behaviour in a new function that effectively turns promises into callbacks. In the example below, I've called it "turnIntoCallback". It receives a function that returns a promise, the callback function, and a certain number of arguments for the first function. turnIntoCallback executes that first function and receives a promise in return. If then is executed, the callback is called with the value provided by the asynchronous function inside the promise for the "OK execution" cases. If instead there's an error, the catch executes and the callback receives the error value for the rejected cases.

let f = function(err, result){
    return new Promise((resolve, reject)=>{
        if (err) reject(err);
        else resolve(result);
    });
}

let turnIntoCallback = function(functionThatReturnsAPromise, aCallback, ...args){
    functionThatReturnsAPromise(args[0], args[1]).then(happyResult => aCallback(null, happyResult)).catch(err => aCallback(err))
}

let myCallback = function(err, happyResult){
    if (err) console.error(err);
    else console.log("Everything went well! " + happyResult);
}

We can try executing the code above with safe parameters and parameters that will cause an error, respectively:

turnIntoCallback(f, myCallback, null, "This is the good ending");
turnIntoCallback(f, myCallback, "This is the bad ending")

In the console we can see the result:

Everything went well! This is the good ending

This is the bad ending

Node actually provides a function to do this automatically, callbackify. It can be thought of as the opposite to promisify.

bodyMarkdown:
**1. Do not run** this in the first place:

`git add file-that-should-not-be-track.ed`

Unless you want to track the file with git. Avoid running `git add` on entire folders.

2\. Add to `.gitignore` the name of the file you do not want git to track.

https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore

3\. However, if the file has already been added, indeed use:

```
git rm --cached X
git commit -m "removed X"
```

title: Yield in Javascript
body:
To protect a variable from external changes coming from WebSocket events when it's in a "delicate" state, we've wrapped it in a mutex (implemented just as a boolean variable). In this case it doesn't synchronize threads, as there's only one in JavaScript, but events.

However, sometimes the flow of the program needs to wait for the mutex to change its state. We wanted to ask if there's something similar to a low-level yield to transform this kind of loops into something more efficient:

while (mutex != true){
    // wait (ideally, yield)
}

bodyMarkdown:
Since in JavaScript there is only 1 thread, there is no need to use locks (and they wouldn't work because there is no other thread to unlock them from).

If the non-deterministic order of events is causing problems, there should be a way for reordering the events so that they are delayed until a certain state is reached, or they are ignored unless when received in a given state.

Also yield exists, but it is used for generator functions, but I suspect they wouldn't be useful in your case.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/yield
